author: Ivy0789
body:
ARKK has speculative risks, sure, but to classify the entire thing as unprofitable crap is not fair. Yes, their larges holding is TSLA (10.5%), which seems to be bubblicious. The second is SQ (7.71%), which I personally belive is poised for rapid growth. Anecdotally, I see SQ terminals all over the place. They hold Z (zillow), PINS, ADSK (auto desk, industry leader), DOCU, and a bunch of others. Not everything in there is unrealistic or unreasonablally priced. 
Take a look at their holdings [ARKK](http://ark-funds.com/arkk)

The fund has been active since OCT 2014. All funds from ARK are actively managed by Cathie Wood, who has been very successful of late. Her whole strategy revolves around the premise that we are seeing rapid expansion in "disruptive innovation" the likes of which hasn't been seen since the late 19th and early 20th century (the invention of the internal combustion engine, electricity being widely adopted, ect). This may not be far off, considering the leaps we have seen in energy storage, space, and robotics in the past decade. Then again, it could be way off base. Do your research! 

In the last year they had a portfolio turnover rate of 80% (meaning they sold 80% of the value of their holdings). They also hold a minor amount of GBTC on occasion, which is a bitcoin grantor trust and can have some tax consequences as the IRS considers BTC to be similar to property for tax purposes. 
If you hold this in a taxable account you may not see returns close to the NAV. 
However, ARKK has returned, on average, 14.01% per annum after taxes on distributions and sale of fund shares, which is nearly double that of SPY. That number is assuming the highest individual federal marginal income tax rate (excluding state taxes, if applicable). 
Take a look at their prospecus for more detailed information. 

TL DR: ARKK and ARK Invest fund in general are not totally bullshit, but they do carry a certain amount of risk. Concentrating your net worth into these funds could prove disastrous, but also could outpace total market performance over the next decade.

author: realwongtime
body:
We use Autodesk for CAD, it works with Mac but most departments that CAD custom build their rigs to be extra GPU heavy so PC is the go to. 

Hardly anyone uses the surface basically only management, it’s honestly such a POS. 

Since everything at MSFT is done through azure the OS really doesn’t matter anything works unless you are Deving for certain platforms.

body: CAD is far and away more of their business than the entertainment divisions of Autodesk by a substantial margin.

author: A_nilsen
body:
I have 4 different strategy of investments, where two of them correlated.

The 5 strategy is currently off and it is a SP500 ETF, I'm not buying not because of FED, more because of the indicators I had mentioned. If they will go to the normal levels I will convert some share of the portfolio to the SP500 ETF or maybe some leverage Index ETF if it be good enough.

First two strategies are become clarified as we enter the Great Commodities Cycle. You can see everywhere, with gold prices, uranium, ore and more. Gold is actually outperform the broad market in the last two years because of this. And it isn't going to stop. The Great Commodities Cycle was predictable because of some rates and graphs, but it a little bit more complicated to explain it here. My good performance is literally from the big hedge with gold against the markets. 

 So how we can earn some money from it? 

1. Just buy Gold (GLD or IUA) and hold for 10 years.
2. Buy commodities connected companies. But you have to choose good ones, with small debt, great management, and good free cash flow.

The 3 strategy is to find "hidden" value companies. Companies with a good history, perfect management, growing sales, but bad times. Not so bad, just for some reasons the news coverage is bad for them right now. It couldn't be a "hype" company like Amazon, it has to be smaller one, who nobody from the newbie investor knows.

It is very complicated strategy, but it is very rewarding one. To find this kind of company a great work needed to be done. A lot of financial data investigated, and a lot of research on the company. But as I said it is very rewarding. Returns on this are very high.

The 4 strategies is to find a flawns, a perfect places to earn some good return in the short period of time. It could be some crazy and unknown commodity or a short. Shorts are very dangerous, cause you play against the market mood, which is forever up. But.

For example I shorted the ADSK, very unusual things to do. If you ask today somebody about ADSK in the reddit, everybody will explain how great the company is, and how good to invest in it. 

I buy short at February this year for 210 and sell it for 140 in the pick of the crisis in March. Making literally nice money from it.

sure, but they are known the be the worst of the bunch still.

author: MrDopple68
body:
First post. Be kind (smiley face thingy).

Over the last 4 months I've built up a portfolio for the next 10+ years. With the Buffett strategy of hold, hold hold, but with mainly growth stocks, not value. I've divided into Big (over 5% of my portfolio), Medium (2 -4%) and Small (1.5% or less).

I'd be grateful if you all can point out the bad choices.

Big: Amazon, Tesla, Disney, Square, Illumina, Roku, Nvidia.

Med: FB, Alphabet, Netflix, Chegg, LuLu, Shopify, Spotify, MercadoLibre, Crowdstrike, The Trade Desk, Tractor Supplies, Walmart, Clorox, Pinterest, Huya, Sea, PayPal, Visa, Twilio, Adobe, Fastly, Docusign, Teladoc, Salesforce, Qualcoom, Skyworks, Waste Man, Starbucks, Invitae, Nike.

Small: 2U, Veeva, Activision, Autodesk, Etsy, Nokia, Pinduoduo, Zoom, TSM, Peloton, Okta, Zscaler, CrispR T, Xlinx, Splunk, Snap, Stratsys, Adyen, Teradyne, Lending Tree, Zillow, Nio.

As I say, I'm investing for the long term. I'm not selling any for short term gain, or trading. Cheers.
